comment.author: 43854658@N00
comment._content: This was the first railroad bridge built to cross the new Cape Cod Canal. It was a single-span bascule drawbridge. The 160-foot bridge was completed in 1910, and, as technogeo said, the grand opening of the Cape Cod Canal was July 29, 1914, [1] "The bridge was able to pivot and a double track ran across it. Because of the anticipated heavy loads, the bridge itself had the [an] immense weight of 1200 tons. Only two, 65-horsepower electric motors were needed to open and close the bridge in only one minute." [2] Unfortunately the original 100-foot wide canal was hopelessly too narrow and too shallow, and did little but lose money for its investors. As a result, the Cape Cod Canal was purchased by the U.S. Government in 1928. The canal was widened and deepened to nearly 500 feet wide and 32 feet deep. A new 544-foot wide vertical lift bridge, known as the Cape Cod Canal Railroad Bridge (also known as the Buzzard's Bay Railroad Bridge), was completed in 1935, and is in use to this day.[3]   The new bridge weighs in at almost twice the weight of the old: 2,050 tons. A 1987 photo by photographer Martin Stupich of the "new" vertical lift bridge, from the collection of The Library of Congress, is shown below:   "General View of Cape Cod Canal Railroad Bridge" by The Library of Congress

I would retain the apostrophe in the photo title here, since that's how Bain's spelled it. But note the photographer's imprint in the lower right corner seems to be missing the apostrophe.

A quick skim through Google Books suggests that the apostrophe was standard through most of the 19th century and started being dropped around the time this photo was taken.

comment._content:
"Because of the anticipated heavy loads, the bridge itself had the [an] immense weight of 1200 tons." With inappropriate editorial license, I inserted the weight of "1200 tons" from the caption of the photograph, into the quote concerning the "massive weight" of the bridge in my original comment (above). This insertion may have brought extra attention to the "massive weight" of the bridge. In any event I have corrected the text in the original comment. I also found a New York Times article from June 16, 1912, that mentioned the 1200 tons:
"The counter balance of the section of the bridge which is lifted hangs at the south end and is filled with 1200 tons of cement."
I gotta say, I dunno how much the bridge weighs! ;-)

comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content:
Commercial America, Volume 11 puts the weight at 2000 tons but doesn't say whether that includes the counterweight. It says the bridge can be opened in 57 seconds. Also that the US government at the time considered paying for a longer span so battleships could go under it, but apparently decided against it.

A 1200 ton counterweight would be about right for a 800 ton leaf, making the total 2000 tons.
